intro: Lippia pohliana, commonly known as Mexican blueweed, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, blue-tinged flowers and serrated leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and streambanks. It produces small, clustered flowers that bloom in the summer months, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Lippia pohliana is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties.
